menu.nav.label: UDOIT Main Navigation
welcome.title: Welcome to
welcome.description: UDOIT helps you through the process of removing accessibility barriers in your online course content.
welcome.scan: Find accessibility barriers quickly with an automated scan.
welcome.fix: Fix issues easily with simple tools and just-in-time instructions.
welcome.report: Make steady progress with small daily goals and easy reporting tools.
summary.title: Accessibility Summary
summary.description: Removing accessibility barriers is an ongoing process, not a one-time project. UDOIT helps you track your progress and make steady improvements.
summary.issues.description: The UDOIT scanner has found {count} issue(s) that almost certainly create accessibility barriers. These should be resolved first as they will most likely directly impact users.
summary.potentials.description: The UDOIT scanner has found {count} potential issue(s) that may create accessibility barriers depending on context. These should be reviewed and then resolved if necessary.
summary.suggestions.description: The UDOIT scanner has found {count} suggestion(s). Suggestions are ways to improve your course content for ease of use, but are not accessibility barriers, and may be reviewed after resolving known and potential barriers.
report.header.name: Name
report.msg.no_results: Try changing the filters or searching with a different keyword
settings.text.about:
About UDOIT

The Universal Design Online content Inspection Tool, or UDOIT (pronounced "You Do It"), is a free and open-source accessibility checker for online course content developed by the University of Central Florida. It downloads and scans course content, finds common accessibility barriers, and provides tools and suggestions for removing them. UDOIT integrates directly with Learning Management Systems so that scanning information is always up-to-date and that fixes made with UDOIT are instantly saved to your online course.
settings.text.tools:
Scanning Toolkit

UDOIT uses the open source IBM Equal Access Checker to scan and identify accessibility barriers. This checker finds most, but not all, accessibility barriers, and is incredibly consistent according to public performance data. While it allows for many configurations, UDOIT scans with the ruleset for WCAG 2.1 AA, which is the legal requirement for state and government institutions under the new rule for the Americans with Disabilities Act.
settings.text.history:
History

  • 2013 - Canvas awards the University of Central Florida a $10,000 innovation grant to begin work on UDOIT.
  • 2015 - UDOIT v1 is released to UCF Faculty in May, and to the public as a free and open-source project in June.
  • 2017 - UDOIT is awarded the Learning Impact Award from IMS Global (now 1EdTech).
  • 2021 - UDOIT v3 is released. This major release included significant work from Cidi Labs, a corporate partner with UCF.
  • 2025 - UDOIT v4 released. This current version includes the new IBM scanning tool, improved reporting, and a more user-friendly interface.
settings.text.roadmap:
Roadmap

UDOIT is currently available for Canvas. Future updates will include support for other popular LMS platforms, including Blackboard, D2L, and Moodle. We are also currently working on a standalone desktop version of the app, which will allow smaller institutions to use the scanning tools without needing an online server setup.
settings.text.disclaimer:
Disclaimer

UDOIT is meant to be used as a guide, not a certification. While it checks for a wide variety of accessibility barriers, and is not comprehensive; a clean report in UDOIT does not necessarily mean that your course is fully accessible. Likewise, the tool may indicate a possible accessibility barrier where one does not exist.
fix.label.no_changes_desc: Only select this option if you have verified that this does not present an accessibility barrier.
fix.msg.no_error_preview: This accessibility barrier cannot be found, likely because the content has been changed. No areas will be highlighted and no changes can be made inside of UDOIT.
fix.msg.select_issue: Select an issue from the list to view its details and either fix it or mark it as reviewed.
fix.msg.resolved: If you have reviewed this issue and determined that it is not an accessibility barrier, you can mark it as reviewed.
fix.msg.unresolved: This issue has been marked as reviewed. If additional changes need to be made, you can mark it as unreviewed.
msg.no_permissions: You do not have permission to access the specified course.
msg.no_new_content: Course scan complete. No new content found.
msg.new_content: Course scan complete. New content has been added.
msg.return_focus: Welcome back to UDOIT! If you have changed any course content, please refresh this page to rescan.
msg.file.replace.file_type: File type not accepted. Please input a file with the correct filetype.
msg.file.replace.file_size: File size too large. Please input a file of a size less than 10MB
msg.sync.course_inactive: Course scan failed. Course is inactive.
msg.settings.update_failed: Failed to save settings. Please try again.
msg.sync.error.api: API call failed. Please refresh the page to try again.
msg.sync.error.connection: Connection to the LMS failed. Please refresh the page to try again.
msg.sync.error.forbidden: You do not have permission to update this course. Please contact an administrator or the course owner.
msg.sync.error.local_save: Content failed to save to the UDOIT database. Please refresh the page and try again.
msg.sync.error.not_found: The issue could not be found. Please refresh the page and try again.
msg.sync.error.unauthorized: You are not authorized to access this course. Please log in again.
content_page.issues.table.caption: Table of issues found
form.error.same_html: There are no changes to save. Please make changes to the issue before saving.
form.alt_text.title: Images Should Have Alternative Text
form.alt_text.summary: Every image that conveys meaning should have a text alternative that clearly describes its content.
form.alt_text.learn_more:
Meaningful Alternative Text

When an image contains important information, providing a text alternative makes the same information available to users who cannot see the image, like users with screen readers or a Braille display.

When an image is only decorative or redundant, like a background or banner image, marking the image as decorative allows assistive technologies to ignore it or not repeat the information.

Best Practices

  • If the image conveys meaning, provide a clear and concise description
  • If the image contains important words, include them in the description
  • If the image is decorative or redundant, mark it so it will be ignored by assistive technologies

For More Information

WebAIM.org: Alternative Text

W3.org: Alternative Text for Images
form.alt_text.msg.text_empty: Alt text is required if an image is not decorative
form.alt_text.msg.text_has_file_extensio: Alt text cannot contain file extensions
form.alt_text.msg.text_matches_filename: Alt text cannot match file name
rule.info.img_alt_decorative: If an image is meant to be decorative, it should not contain any alternative text. Marking it as decorative here will remove the alternative text.
rule.info.img_alt_redundant: This image has alternative text, but it may be redundant based on the surrounding text. If the description is present elsewhere, you should mark this image as decorative.
form.anchor_text.title: Links Should Contain Descriptive Text
form.anchor_text.summary: Every link should have descriptive text that clearly indicates where the link will take the user, not just "click here" or "more info".
form.anchor_text.learn_more:
Link Text

Screen readers generate a list of all the links on a page for blind users to efficiently navigate to desired content. In this context, multiple “read more” links on a page will only confuse users. Meaningful stand-alone link text is also helpful for users with cognitive disabilities.

Best Practices

  • Provide clear and concise link text that can be understood out of context
  • Contextualize generic links such as “read more”

For More Information

WebAIM.org: Links and Hypertext
form.aria_attribute.title: ARIA Attributes Must Have Valid Values
form.aria_attribute.summary: ARIA attributes are used to provide additional context for screen readers, but they must have valid values to work properly.
form.aria_attribute.learn_more:
ARIA Attributes

ARIA (Accessible Rich Internet Applications) attributes are used to provide important information about the purpose of a HTML element. When ARIA attributes are added to a HTML element, they can provide additional context that helps screen readers know how to present information.

However, using an invalid value can cause confusion for users of assistive technologies.

Best Practices

  • Avoid using ARIA attributes that are not necessary
  • Only use ARIA attributes with valid values

For More Information

W3.org: No ARIA is Better than Bad ARIA, Author Guidance to Avoid Incorrect Use of ARIA
form.aria_attribute.name: ARIA Attribute
form.aria_attribute.label.select: Select a Valid ARIA Attribute Value
form.aria_attribute.msg.attribute_requir: If an ARIA attribute is present, it must have a valid value
rule.info.aria_attribute_conflict: This HTML element is a/an <{tagName}>, but has an ARIA attribute of {ariaAttribute}, which is invalid or incompatible.
form.aria_role.title: HTML Element has an Incompatible ARIA Role
form.aria_role.summary: ARIA roles are often used to provide needed context for screen readers, but many HTML elements have built-in roles that sometimes conflict.
form.aria_role.learn_more:
ARIA Roles

ARIA (Accessible Rich Internet Applications) roles are used to provide important information about the purpose of a HTML element. Usually, roles are based on the HTML code and don't need to be added manually. For instance, every <button> automatically has the role of "button" and every <form> has the role of "form".

When ARIA roles are added to an HTML element, they can provide additional context that helps screen readers know how to present information. However, using an incompatible role can cause confusion for users of assistive technologies.

Best Practices

  • Avoid using ARIA roles that are not necessary
  • Only use ARIA roles that are compatible with the HTML element

For More Information

W3.org: No ARIA is Better than Bad ARIA, ARIA Examples by Role, Author Guidance to Avoid Incorrect Use of ARIA
form.aria_role.feedback.no_tag: The HTML tag could not be computed
form.aria_role.msg.role_required: If an ARIA role is present, it must be compatible with the HTML element
rule.info.aria_role_valid: This HTML element is a/an <{tagName}>, but has an ARIA role of "{ariaRole}", which is incompatible.
form.blockquote.title: Blockquotes Must Have a Citation
form.blockquote.summary: Blockquotes are used to indicate that a section of text is a quotation from another source. Do not use blockquotes just for indentation or visual style.
form.blockquote.learn_more:
Blockquotes

Blockquotes are used to indicate that a section of text is a quotation from another source. They should always include a citation to the original source of the quote. If the citation is already included in text directly above or below the blockquote, you may choose to hide the citation inside the blockquote, even though it still must be added here.

Best Practices

  • Include a citation for every blockquote
  • Blockquotes should never be used just for indentation or visual style
  • The citation can be the name of the book or article, the name of the author, or a URL

For More Information

W3.org: Using Semantic Markup

Mozilla.org: The Block Quotation element
form.blockquote.text.placeholder: e.g. title of book or article, author name, or URL
form.blockquote.label.hide_citation_desc: Only use this option if the citation is already included in the page text.
form.contrast.title: Text Must Have Sufficient Color Contrast with the Background
form.contrast.summary: Text must have sufficient contrast with the background color to be readable by users with low vision or color blindness.
form.contrast.learn_more:
Color Contrast

Users with low vision need sufficient contrast in order to read. The color contrast ratio follows a formula to compare the luminance of the foreground text with background colors. Take note of contrast especially for text resizing, responsive design, and motion effects like parallax or animated backgrounds when the position of text on its background can change.

Best Practices

  • Make sure text achieves sufficient contrast against its background
  • Achieve maximum contrast for all text placed over images or gradients

For More Information

WebAIM.org: Contrast and Color Accessibility

Online Color Contrast Checker
form.contrast.label.adjust: Adjust the Text and/or Background Colors to Increase Contrast
form.embedded_content_title.title: Embedded Content Should Have a Label
form.embedded_content_title.summary: Embedded content, like videos or interactive elements, should have descriptive labels that help users understand what it is and what it does.
form.embedded_content_title.learn_more:
Descriptive Labels

For users with screen readers, embedded content requires them to manually enter and "zoom in" to explore what's there. Providing a label is like having a sign on a door that describes what's inside. With this information, a user can determine whether they want to enter and explore in detail.

Best Practices

  • When embedding content, make sure the embed code includes a title attribute with a unique label that describes its contents
form.embedded_content_title.label.text: Add Descriptive Label for Highlighted Content
rule.info.media_alt_brief: Labels should be concise (aim for less than 150 characters).
form.emphasis.title: Information Should Not be Conveyed by Color Alone
form.emphasis.summary: Color should never be the only way that information is conveyed. Descriptive text or other visual cues like icons may be required.
form.emphasis.learn_more:
Color Alone is Insufficient

When conveying information, it is important that color isn't the only way it is being presented. For instance, when using red and green to indicate good/bad or different colors in a pie chart, additional text or visual cues are necessary.

With text, this may mean including icons, numbers, or additional styles like bold or italic. For charts and graphs, it may mean using colors with high contrast or different sorts of fill patterns.

Best Practices

  • Make sure that all information conveyed by color differences is also available in text
  • In addition to color, use numbers, lists, icons, fill patterns, or additional styles to highlight differences

For More Information

WebAIM.org: Color-blindness

W3.org: Don't Use Color Alone to Convey Information
form.emphasis.label.select_emphasis: Select Additional Ways to Distinguish Text
form.emphasis.msg.required: Emphasized text should be bold or italicized
form.file.title: Files Should Be Reviewed for Accessibility
form.file.summary: Files like PDFs, Word documents, and PowerPoint presentations can often be made accessible if they are created using the built-in tools and features of the software.
form.file.pdf.learn_more:
Accessible PDF Files

Similar to web pages, PDF files can provide hidden "tags" which provide additional context for screen readers about the document structure and content. When saving or exporting PDFs, be sure to select the "tagged" option, if available. Untagged PDFs are not considered accessible.

Best Practices

  • Always save and export PDFs with tags to ensure accessibility

For More Information

WebAIM.org: PDF Accessibility
form.file.doc.learn_more:
Accessible Word Documents

Word documents can be accessible if they are created using Word as it was designed, but many people don't use its built-in features properly. For instance, headings are accessible if created using Word's "Heading" styles. However, most users create headings by highlighting text and applying changes to fonts, sizes, and formatting. While these sections may visually look like headers, they are not part of the document structure that screen readers use to navigate.

Best Practices

  • Use built-in headings and lists; don't style text or change font settings yourself
  • Use the built-in alt text tool for images
  • Use the built-in table tools to create tables
  • Use the built-in accessibility checker

For More Information

WebAIM.org: Creating Accessible Documents
form.file.ppt.learn_more:
Accessible Presentations

When creating a slide show presentation, content should be clear and understandable for all learners. If the presentation will be viewed on a projector, make sure that text is not too small. If the file is meant to be downloaded, consider exporting it as a PDF, which has wider support.

Best Practices

  • Text and background colors should have high contrast
  • Do not use color alone to convey information
  • If available, use a built-in accessibility checker

For More Information

WebAIM.org: PowerPoint Accessibility
form.file.xls.learn_more:
Accessible Excel Files

Spreadsheets are relatively easy to navigate for screenreaders, but can sometimes be visually overwhelming or difficult to read when text is too small or spaced too closely together. Using slightly larger fonts and adding visual space can help make spreadsheets easier to understand.

Best Practices

  • Add extra width and height to cells to enhance readability
  • Remove or hide unnecessary blank rows and columns between sections of data
  • Freeze rows and columns as necessary to ensure that headers are consistently visible

For More Information

WebAIM.org: Optimizing Spreadsheet Accessibility
form.file.label.replace.desc: If necessary, replace the current version of this file here:
form.heading_empty.title: Headings Should Not Be Empty
form.heading_empty.summary: Headings should not be empty. If a heading is not needed, it should be removed instead.
form.heading_empty.learn_more:
Heading Structure

Users who rely on screen readers depend heavily on headings to help them quickly understand and navigate page content. Organized headings create a clear outline of the page and allow users to find what they need quickly and easily.

Never create headings by styling text alone, like using larger or bolded fonts and colors. Screen readers don't distinguish between text of different sizes. Instead, use Heading elements, which not only style the text consistently, but allow screen readers to isolate and skip to headings as needed.

Headings can be thought of as indents on a written outline: the bigger the number, the further indented that portion of the outline would be. The first heading is H1, then H2, all the way to H6. A heading should never be more than one number higher (one level deeper) than the heading just before it.

Best Practices

  • Describe sections of content with accurate, succinct headings
  • Never use styles alone to create headings: use Heading elements
  • Every page should have 1 top-level heading (H1), which is usually the page title; every other heading should be H2 through H6
  • Avoid skipping levels

For More Information

WebAIM.org: Headings
form.heading_style.title: Headings Should Show Page Structure
form.heading_style.summary: Headings should be used to create a clear structure for the page content, allowing users to navigate easily. Never create headings by styling text alone.
form.heading_style.learn_more:
Heading Structure

Users who rely on screen readers depend heavily on headings to help them quickly understand and navigate page content. Organized headings create a clear outline of the page and allow users to find what they need quickly and easily.

Never create headings by styling text alone, like using larger or bolded fonts and colors. Screen readers don't distinguish between text of different sizes. Instead, use Heading elements, which not only style the text consistently, but allow screen readers to isolate and skip to headings as needed.

Headings can be thought of as indents on a written outline: the bigger the number, the further indented that portion of the outline would be. The first heading is H1, then H2, all the way to H6. A heading should never be more than one number higher (one level deeper) than the heading just before it.

Best Practices

  • Describe sections of content with accurate, succinct headings
  • Never use styles alone to create headings: use Heading elements
  • Every page should have 1 top-level heading (H1), which is usually the page title; every other heading should be H2 through H6
  • Avoid skipping levels

For More Information

WebAIM.org: Headings
rule.info.heading_markup_misuse: This text is marked as a heading, but does not appear to be one. If it is, you may ignore this issue and mark it as reviewed. If it is not a heading, remove the heading level.
rule.info.text_block_heading: This text seems to be a heading, but is not marked as one. If it is a heading, select an appropriate heading level. If not, you may remove any styling or mark that no changes are needed.
form.invalid_attribute.title: HTML Element has an Invalid Attribute
form.invalid_attribute.summary: HTML elements should not have attributes that are not valid for that element. This can cause confusion for screen readers and other assistive technologies.
form.invalid_attribute.learn_more:
Valid Attributes

Each type of HTML element is allowed to have specific attributes that affect how it looks, how it functions, and how it interacts with other elements on a page. For instance, every image (<img>) element can have an alt attribute, which supplies it with alternative text for screen readers. However, for most other elements (like <nav>, <footer>, and <details>), the alt attribute is not allowed. Furthermore, many attributes have a limited number of valid options. The dir attribute, for example, determines which direction text is displayed, and is only allowed to have the values of ltr (left-to-right), rtl (right-to-left), and auto. Using an invalid attribute or giving an attribute an invalid tag can cause confusion for screen readers and other assistive technologies.

Best Practices

  • Only use valid attributes for each HTML element
  • Make sure that the values you give each attribute are valid
  • If you aren't sure how to use an attribute, an online search with the keywords 'HTML' and 'attribute' should yield very good results

For More Information

W3schools.com: HTML Attribute Reference

WebAIM.org HTML Semantics and Accessibility Cheat Sheet
rule.info.aria_attribute_redundant: The HTML attribute of {htmlAttribute} makes the ARIA attribute of {ariaAttribute} redundant. You should remove {ariaAttribute} to avoid potential conflicts.
rule.info.dir_attribute_valid: The dir attribute can only be given the values of ltr (left-to-right), rtl (right-to-left), and auto
rule.info.input_autocomplete_valid: The autocomplete attribute can only be given the values of on, off, or another valid value.
rule.info.input_haspopup_conflict: The <input> element has a list attribute along with a aria-haspopup attribute, which is redundant and should be removed.
rule.info.table_aria_descendants: Elements inside a table (<tr>, <th>, and <td>) should not have the role attribute.
rule.info.table_scope_valid: th elements inside a table should have a scope attribute with the value of row, col, rowgroup, or colgroup.
form.keyboard_tabbable.title: Interactive Elements Must Be Keyboard Accessible
form.keyboard_tabbable.summary: Interactive elements, like links, buttons, and form fields, should be reached and activated with the keyboard alone.
form.keyboard_tabbable.learn_more:
Keyboard Accessibility

Some users cannot use a mouse or trackpad due to physical limitations. When this is the case, they may have a custom device that helps them navigate. These devices translate interactions, from rough muscle control to voice commands, into equivalent keystrokes.

For this reason, it is important that all interactive elements can be reached and activated using the keyboard alone. This includes links, buttons, form fields, and other interactive elements. The primary way keyboard users skip between interactive elements is by pressing Tab to go forward and Shift + Tab to go backward.

Best Practices

  • Use the tabindex="0" attribute to force an element into the list of places that can be reached using the Tab key, or the tabindex="-1" attribute to remove it
  • Test your content to make sure that all interactive elements can be reached and activated using the keyboard alone

For More Information

WebAIM.org: Keyboard Accessibility

W3.org: Keyboard (Level A)
rule.info.aria_activedescendant_tabindex: The highlighted element has an aria-activedescendant attribute, which requires it to be interactive. If it is supposed to be interactive, add the attribute tabindex="0". Otherwise, remove the conflicting attribute.
rule.info.element_scrollable_tabbable: The highlighted area seems to be scrollable. For keyboard user to scroll up and down, the area must be added to the keyboard navigation.
rule.info.element_tabbable_role_valid: The highlighted element can be reached by keyboard, but has a role that is not interactive. If it is supposed to be interactive, remove the role or change it to a valid widget role. Otherwise, add the attribute tabindex="-1".
rule.info.iframe_interactive_tabbable: If this embedded content is interactive, it must be added to the keyboard navigation.
form.label.title: Interactive and Landmark Areas Should Have Labels
form.label.summary: Interactive elements like buttons, links, and form fields should have descriptive labels that help users understand their purpose. Landmark regions should also have unique labels to help users navigate the page.
form.label.learn_more:
Navigating Using Landmarks

Web content is typically laid out in consistent patterns: a header at the top, page navigation menus, main content, sidebars, footers, etc. Standard sections are known as "landmarks," and they help assistive technology (AT) users orient themselves and easily navigate to various regions of a page. When multiple regions with the same role exist on the same page (imagine two "navigation" menus or a long page with multiple "articles"), people using ATs may have difficulty identifying or distinguishing between them.

Landmarks are created by using specific HTML tags, like <nav>, <main>, and <footer>, or by adding the role attribute to a generic tag, like role="navigation".

Importantly, some landmarks are only allowed to be used once per page. If you have multiple of these landmarks, you will need to remove the extras or change their role values.
HTML Landmarks and Equivalent Role Values
HTML TagEquivalent RoleAllowed Once
<header>role="banner"Yes
<nav>role="navigation"No
N/Arole="search"No
<aside>role="complementary"No
<main>role="main"Yes
<h1>N/AYes
<article>role="article"No
<section>role="region"No
<form>role="form"No
<footer>role="contentinfo"Yes

Best Practices

  • Use unique aria-label values to distinguish landmarks with the same role
  • Make sure that there is only one landmark each of <header>, <main>, <h1>, and <footer>

For More Information

WebAIM.org: Semantic Structure and ARIA Landmark Roles

W3.org: Landmark Regions
form.label.label.text: Add Descriptive Label for Highlighted Area
rule.info.element_accesskey_labelled: The highlighted element has an accesskey attribute, which provides a keyboard shortcut to activate it. You should add a label so that users know what the shortcut does.
rule.info.label_name_visible: The highlighted element has a visible label, but its screen reader label doesn't match. You can either update the screen reader label to match the visible label, or remove it.
form.label_unique.title: Labels Should Be Unique
form.label_unique.summary: When using landmarks, it is important to provide unique labels for each one. This allows users of assistive technologies to easily navigate and understand the content on the page.
form.label_unique.learn_more:
Unique Labels

Web content is typically laid out in consistent patterns: a header at the top, page navigation menus, main content, sidebars, footers, etc. Standard sections are known as "landmarks," and they help assistive technology (AT) users orient themselves and easily navigate to various regions of a page. When multiple regions with the same role exist on the same page (imagine two "navigation" menus or a long page with multiple "articles"), people using ATs may have difficulty identifying or distinguishing between them.

For example, if you have two navigation menus on a page, you should provide unique labels for each menu so that users can differentiate between them.

HTML Landmarks and Equivalent Role Values
HTML TagEquivalent RoleAllowed Once
<header>role="banner"Yes
<nav>role="navigation"No
N/Arole="search"No
<aside>role="complementary"No
<main>role="main"Yes
<h1>N/AYes
<article>role="article"No
<section>role="region"No
<form>role="form"No
<footer>role="contentinfo"Yes

Best Practices

  • Use unique aria-label values to distinguish landmarks with the same role
  • Make sure that there is only one landmark each of <header>, <main>, <h1>, and <footer>

For More Information

WebAIM.org: Semantic Structure and ARIA Landmark Roles

W3.org: Using ARIA Landmarks
form.language.title: Languages Should be Specified Correctly
form.language.summary: Web pages should always specify what language they are in. Any text that is in another language should also be specified correctly.
form.language.learn_more:
Language Specification

Web pages should always specify their primary language. This allows screen readers to pronounce text correctly and makes it possible for web browsers to translate the text into other languages.

When a small portion of text is in a language other than the page's primary language, it should be marked with the lang attribute and the appropriate language code. For example, if a page is in English but includes a quote in Spanish, the quote should be marked with lang="es". More specifically, your code may look like this: <p>The tourist walked up to me and asked, <span lang="fr">"Excusez-moi, parlez-vous français?"</span></p>

Every language has a specific two-letter code that is assigned by the IANA, and is recognized globally. Using the wrong language code will result in browsers and screen readers not understanding which language was intended. If the language you're looking for is not in the following list of commonly-used languages, visit this complete list of language codes.

Common Language Codes
LanguageCode
Englishen
Spanishes
Frenchfr
Germande
Italianit
Portuguesept
Chinesezh
Japaneseja
Russianru
Arabicar
Hindihi

Best Practices

  • Always specify the primary language of the page in the <html> tag using the lang attribute
  • Use the lang attribute to mark any text in other languages

For More Information

W3.org: Declaring Language in HTML, Language of Parts

WebAIM.org: Document and Content Language
form.link.title: Links Should Contain Text
form.link.summary: Links should have descriptive text that clearly indicates where the link will take the user, not just "click here" or "more info".
form.link.learn_more:
Link Text

Screen readers generate a list of all the links on a page for blind users to efficiently navigate to desired content. In this context, multiple "read more" links on a page will only confuse users. Meaningful stand-alone link text is also helpful for users with cognitive disabilities.

Best Practices

  • Provide clear and concise link text that can be understood out of context
  • Contextualize generic links such as "read more"

For More Information

WebAIM.org: Links and Hypertext
form.list.title: Lists Should Have Proper List Markup
form.list.summary: When lists are not marked up correctly, it can be difficult for users with assistive technologies to navigate and understand the content.
form.list.learn_more:
List Markup

Lists are an effective way to structure complex or lengthy content. But when lists are not marked up correctly, it can be difficult for users with assistive technologies to navigate and understand the content.

Simply typing in dashes, asterisks, or numbers at the beginning of a paragraph is insufficient. Every list should be specifically identified as either an unordered list (<ul>, which appears with dots or dashes), and an ordered list (<ol>, which labels each item with numbers or letters). And every item in the list should be designated as a list item (<li>). The easiest way to accomplish this is to use a List tool inside your content editor.

Best Practices

  • Always use the list tool when making lists in a content editor; DO NOT make lists manually by typing numbers or symbols.
  • Use <ul> for unordered lists and <ol> for ordered lists
  • Use <li> for each item in the list

For More Information

WebAIM.org: Semantic Structure: Lists

W3.org: Content Structure: Lists
rule.info.list_markup_review: This text seems to be part of a list, but is not marked as one. If it is a list, modify it in your LMS using the list tools. Otherwise, no changes are needed.
form.media_captions.title: Media Should Have Captions and Transcripts
form.media_captions.summary: Videos and audio files should have captions or transcripts to ensure that all users can access the content, including those with hearing disabilities or those who speak different languages.
form.media_captions.learn_more:
Media Captions and Transcripts

Captions and transcripts are helpful, not only for people with hearing disabilities, but also for those who speak foreign languages or have learning disabilities or processing disorders. Timed captions that are synchronized with videos are usually applied to that video directly by the video creator or hosting service.

If you cannot add captions to a video, you must include a written transcript instead.

Best Practices

  • Provide transcripts for all audio and video content
  • Provide captions for video content (audio-only media like podcasts don't require captions)
  • Where possible, use built-in captioning tools in your video platform or LMS

For More Information

WebAIM.org: Captions, Transcripts, and Audio Descriptions
form.media_captions.label.description: UDOIT cannot automatically detect whether videos hosted on external sites have captions. Please check the item yourself and ensure that captions and transcripts are available. If they are, mark this issue as reviewed.
form.review_only.title: Unable to Fix Inside of UDOIT
form.review_only.summary: This issue cannot be fixed inside of UDOIT. You will need to make changes in your LMS content editor.
form.multi_part.title: Multi-Part Elements Must Be Nested Correctly
form.multi_part.summary: Multi-Part elements require specific "child" elements to be nested inside specific "parent" elements in order to function properly. For example, list items must be inside of a list, and table cells must be inside of a table row.
form.multi_part.learn_more:
Multi-Part Elements

In order to display and function properly, many web page elements require multiple parts. While the following tables are more comprehensive, two common examples are lists and tables.

Lists come in two types: ordered lists (<ol>, which begin each item with a number or letter), and unordered lists (<ul>, which begin each item with a dash or bullet). Regardless of which of these two list types are being used, every list requires one or more list items (<li>). Without these list items, the empty list may create visual spacing problems on the page as well as confuse screen readers and other assistive technologies as they try to parse the content.

Tables also can cause problems if they don't have the expected structure. Every <table> is required to have at least one row (<tr>), and every row must have at least one cell (<td>). Without the expected rows and cells, not only will the table display unpredictably, but the table content will not respond correctly to keyboard controls.

Required Parents and Required Children

"Parent" elements, like <table>, contain "child" elements, like <tr>, nested inside of them. Not only are child elements required to be placed inside the correct parent element, but many parent elements require specific child elements as well. In both cases, missing the companion elements will cause issues not only with assistive technology, but with the page displaying and functioning properly at all.

Table-Specific HTML Child Elements and Their Required Parents
Child HTML Element(s)Required HTML Parent(s)
<caption> (table caption: should always be a table's first nested element)<table>
<colgroup> (column group: if used, should be after caption and before headers or rows)<table>
<col> (column)<table> → <colgroup>
<thead>, <tbody>, and <tfoot> (table header, body, and footer)<table>
<tr> (table row)<table> → <thead>,
<table> → <tbody>, or
<table> → <tfoot>
<th> (table header cell),
<td> (table data cell)		<table> → <thead> → <tr>,
<table> → <tbody> → <tr>, or
<table> → <tfoot> → <tr>
Other HTML Child Elements and Their Required Parents
Nested HTML Element(s)Required HTML Parent(s)
<area> (clickable area)<map> (image map)
<dt> (term),
<dd> (definition)		<dl> (description list)
<legend> (form group label)<fieldset> (form group)
<li> (list item)<ol> (ordered list) or
<ul> (unordered list)
<option> (selectable option),
<optgroup> (option group)		<select> (drop-down list)
<param> (parameter)<object> (external resource)
<source> (source file),
<track> (subtitle file)		<audio>, <video>
ARIA Child Roles and Their Required Parents
Child ARIA Role(s)Required Parent ARIA Role(s)
"caption""figure", "grid", "table", or "treegrid"
"cell", "columnheader", "gridcell", "rowheader""row"
"listitem""directory" or "list"
"menuitem", "menuitemcheckbox", "menuitemradio""group", "menu", or "menubar"
"option""group" or "listbox"
"row""grid", "rowgroup", "table", or "treegrid"
"rowgroup""grid", "table", or "treegrid"
"tab""tablist"
"treeitem""group" or "tree"
ARIA Parent Roles and Their Required Children
Parent ARIA RoleRequired Child ARIA Role(s)
"feed""article"
"grid""row" or "rowgroup" → "row"
"list""listitem"
"listbox""option" or "group" → "option"
"menu" and "menubar""menuitem" or "group" → "menuitem",
"menuitemcheckbox" or "group" → "menuitemcheckbox",
"menuitemradio" or "group" → "menuitemradio"
"radiogroup""radio"
"row""cell", "columnheader", "gridcell", or "rowheader"
"rowgroup""row"
"table" and "treegrid""row" or "rowgroup" → "row"
"tablist""tab"
"tree""treeitem" or "group" → "treeitem"

Best Practices

  • Use semantic HTML elements, such as <ul>, <ol>, and <table>, instead of ARIA roles when possible
  • Ensure that all elements with ARIA roles that require child elements contain the necessary child elements
  • Test the content with a screen reader and keyboard to ensure that it is fully accessible

For More Information

W3.org: Widget Roles, Required Owned Elements

Mozilla.org: WAI-ARIA Roles
rule.info.aria_child_valid: The highlighted parent element has the "{parentRole}" role, which must contain at least one element with the "{childRole}" role.
rule.info.aria_parent_required: The highlighted child element has the "{childRole}" role, which must be nested inside an element with the "{parentRole}" role.
rule.info.fieldset_label_valid: This <fieldset> requires a unique <legend> to describe the group of related form fields.
rule.info.fieldset_legend_valid: This <fieldset> requires a unique <legend> to describe the group of related form fields.
rule.info.figure_label_exists: This <figure> is missing a descriptive <figcaption>. Please add a caption that describes the image's purpose and content.
rule.info.table_caption_nested: This <table> is missing a descriptive <caption>. Please add a caption that describes the table's purpose and content.
form.select_valid_id.title: IDs Must Be Referenced Correctly
form.select_valid_id.summary: IDs are used to connect different elements to each other, but in order to work they must be unique and correctly referenced in links or labels.
form.select_valid_id.learn_more:
Referencing IDs

IDs are used to connect different elements to each other, like a label to a input field or a link to a specific section of a page. This is important because it allows screen readers to identify which on-screen labels apply to which fields and read them correctly.

IDs are hidden inside the bracketed code of an HTML tag, and never show up on-screen. IDs must be unique, meaning that no two elements on the same page can have the same ID. IDs are also case-sensitive, so if a textbox had the attribute of id='FirstName' and the label next to it had the attribute of for='firstname', they would not connect properly, no matter how close they are visually on the screen.

Different Ways to Reference an ID

While IDs are always and only given with the id attribute, they are referenced differently depending on the way they are used. Input fields use the for attribute, table cells use the headers attribute, and links use a #.

Input Field Example

Input Field: <input type="text" id="email">

Linked Label: <label for="email">Email:</label>

Specific Links

Link Destination: <h2 id="part2">Page Heading</h2>

Link: <a href="page.html#part2">Link to Heading</a>

Complex Tables

Table Headers: <th id="event-id">Event</th> and <th id="start-id">Start Time</th>

Table Cell: <td headers="start-id event-id">1:00pm</td>

Screen readers would read: "Event Start Time: 1:00pm" when this cell is focused on.

Best Practices

  • Ensure that all IDs on the same page are unique
  • Reference IDs correctly in links and labels

For More Information

W3.org: Using Label Elements

WebAIM.org: Decoding Label and Name
rule.info.aria_complementary_label_visib: The highlighted area requires a visible, on-screen label. Please select the on-screen text that best labels this area.
rule.info.aria_main_label_visible: The highlighted area requires a visible, on-screen label. Please select the on-screen text that best labels this area.
form.sensory_misuse.title: Instructions Should Not Rely on Shape, Size, or Location
form.sensory_misuse.summary: Instructions should not rely on visual characteristics such as shape, size, or location. This can create barriers for users with visual impairments or cognitive disabilities.
form.sensory_misuse.learn_more:
Clear Instructions

When writing instructions, avoid using visual characteristics such as shape, size, or location. For instance, "Use the description on the RIGHT," "Select the BLUE option," or "Click the SQUARE button" can be problematic for users who cannot see an object or its location on the screen.

However, if the text is NOT instructions, this rule can be ignored, such as "RIGHT BELOW the surface..." or "LEFT to their own devices...".

Best Practices

  • Use instructions that don't depend on shape, size, or location
  • Use a visible text label for the object or area described, like "Left Delete Button"
form.sensory_misuse.label.instructions: Make Sure There Aren't Any Instructions that Depend on These Sensory Words:
form.table_caption.title: Tables Should Have Descriptive Captions
form.table_caption.summary: Tables that contain data should have a caption or title linked to the table to help users understand the content.
form.table_caption.learn_more:
Table Captions

If a table contains data, it should have a caption or title. Just adding text above or below the table isn't enough; each <table> needs to have a <caption> inside it. Using a <caption> allows screen readers to navigate directly to the title and associate it with the correct table.

Best Practices

  • Give every <table> a <caption> with a clear and descriptive title

For More Information

WebAIM.org: Table Captions

W3.org: Caption & Summary
form.table_caption.label.remove_caption_: Only use this option if the table does not contain data.
form.table_headers.title: Tables with Data Should Have Headers
form.table_headers.summary: Data tables should have headers clearly marked in the code. Making a header's text bold or changing its alignment is insufficient.
form.table_headers.learn_more:
Table Headers

Data tables should have headers to help users understand the data. This is especially important for screen reader users, who may not be able to see the table layout. For simple tables, you can define the first row, first column, or both as headers. If your table is more complicated, you may need to use the scope attribute for headers or the headers attribute for cells to indicate which headers apply to which cells.

Best Practices

  • Tables should only be used for presenting data, not to manage page layout
  • Use table-building tools in your LMS to define headers for rows and columns

For More Information

WebAIM.org: Accessible Data Tables

W3.org: Tables Tutorial
form.table_headers.selection_description: Select a Direction for Table Header(s)
form.table_headers.decoration_only_desc: Only use this option if the table does not contain data.
rule.info.table_structure_misuse: This table seems to be decorative, but also has data-related elements, like <th> or <caption>. If this table contains data, please select the appropriate header option instead.
rule.desc.AnchorLinksToSoundFilesNeedTra: Links To Sound Files Need Transcripts
rule.desc.BaseFontIsNotUsed: Base Font Tag Should Not Be Used
rule.desc.BlinkIsNotUsed: Blink Tag Should Not Be Used
rule.desc.ContentTooLong: Content Length Should Not Exceed 3000 Words
rule.desc.CssTextHasContrast: Insufficient Color Contrast Between Text and Background
rule.desc.CssTextStyleEmphasize: Avoid Using Color Alone for Emphasis
rule.desc.EmbedTagDetected: Embedded Content May Be Inaccessible on Mobile Devices
rule.desc.FontIsNotUsed: Font Tag Should Not Be Used
rule.desc.HeadingsInOrder: Heading Levels Should Not Be Skipped
rule.desc.ImageAltIsDifferent: Alternative Text Should Not Be the Image Filename
rule.desc.ImageAltIsTooLong: Alternative Text Is More Than the Maximum Allowed Characters
rule.desc.ImageAltNotEmptyInAnchor: Alt Text For Images Within Links Should Not Be Empty
rule.desc.ImageAltNotPlaceholder: Images Should Not Have a Placeholder as Alternative Text
rule.desc.ImageHasAlt: Image Elements Should Have an "alt" Attribute
rule.desc.ImageHasAltDecorative: Decorative Images Should Have Empty Alternative Text
rule.desc.InputImageNotDecorative: Input Images Should Have an "alt" Attribute
rule.desc.MarqueeIsNotUsed: Marquee Tag Should Not Be Used
rule.desc.NoHeadings: Headings Should Be Used in Content
rule.desc.ObjectMustContainText: Multimedia Objects Should Have Text Equivalents
rule.desc.ParagraphNotUsedAsHeader: Avoid Using Styles for Document Structure
rule.desc.PreShouldNotBeUsedForTabularVa: "Pre" Elements Should Not Be Used for Tabular Data
rule.desc.TableHeaderShouldHaveScope: No Row or Column Scope Declarations Found in Table Headers
rule.desc.VideoCaptionsMatchCourseLangua: Closed Captions Do Not Match Course Language
rule.desc.VideoProvidesCaptions: Video Tags Must have Caption Track
rule.summary.a_target_warning: When links open in a new window or tab, inform users beforehand with text such as "(opens in new window)". This helps users with cognitive disabilities and those using screen readers understand what to expect.
rule.summary.application_content_accessi: When using the role="application" attribute, ensure that all content is accessible to screen readers and keyboard users. This role is typically only used for interactive widgets.
rule.desc.application_content_accessible:
Interactive Applications

The role="application" attribute is used to indicate that a section of a web page contains an interactive application, such as a map or a game. When this role is applied, screen readers switch from their default "document" mode to "application" mode, which changes how they interact with the content.

When using the role="application" attribute, only focusable elements are accessible to screen readers and keyboard users. This means that any non-focusable elements, such as plain text or images, will be ignored by screen readers and cannot be reached using a keyboard. Unless these elements are purely decorative, they must be implemented in an accessible way.

Best Practices

  • If text is a label or description of an interactive element, give the text an id and use the aria-labelledby or aria-describedby attribute to reference to the text
  • Place important text or images inside a focusable element that has the role="document" or role="article" attribute
  • Test the application with a screen reader and keyboard to ensure that it is fully accessible

For More Information

W3.org: The "application" Role, Developing a Keyboard Interface

Mozilla.org: ARIA: Application Role
rule.desc.aria_activedescendant_valid: Certain interactive components, like comboboxes and textboxes, are required to use the aria-activedescendant attribute to indicate which element is currently active.
rule.summary.aria_activedescendant_valid:
Composite Widgets

Most interactive elements on a web page are simple and self-contained. For instance, a text <input> element can be clicked on, typed in, either active or disabled, and update its content without any other element (although you should have it linked to a <label> for accessibility).

However, some interactive elements are more complex and require multiple elements to work together. These are known as "composite widgets," and include elements like comboboxes, listboxes, menus, and treeviews. When using composite widgets, it is important to use the aria-activedescendant attribute to indicate which part of the widget is currently active.

For instance, drop-down selection widgets like a navigation menu can include a composite "container" widget with multiple selectable options that belong to it. Each option should have a unique id, and the container would use the aria_activedescendant attribute to point to whichever option is currently selected. This allows screen readers and keyboard users to understand which element they are interacting with.

Best Practices

  • Use the aria-activedescendant attribute on the container element of a composite widget to reference the currently active child element
  • Ensure that the active child element has a unique id that matches the value of the aria-activedescendant attribute
  • Test the composite widget with a screen reader and keyboard to ensure that it is fully accessible

For More Information

W3.org: Keyboard Navigation Inside Components

Mozilla.org: ARIA: aria-activedescendant Attribute
rule.summary.aria_banner_single: Every page should only have one header, which can be either a <header> element or another element with a role="banner". Please remove the extra headers or change their roles.
rule.summary.aria_contentinfo_misuse: <footer> elements should only be used on pages with <main> elements.
rule.desc.aria_contentinfo_misuse:
Navigating Using Landmarks

Web content is typically laid out in consistent patterns: a header at the top, page navigation menus, main content, sidebars, footers, etc. Standard sections are known as "landmarks," and they help assistive technology (AT) users orient themselves and easily navigate to various regions of a page.

Not every page needs all of these landmarks. For instance, a simple landing page may only have a header and a footer, while a more complex page may have multiple sections and sidebars. However, if a page has a <footer> element, it must also have a <main> element that contains the page's primary information.

Best Practices

  • Ensure that pages use predictable landmarks to simplify navigation
  • All pages should have a <main> element which contains the page's primary content

For More Information

WebAIM.org: Semantic Structure and ARIA Landmark Roles

W3.org: Using ARIA Landmarks
rule.summary.aria_contentinfo_single: Every page should only have one footer, which can be either a <footer> element or another element with a role="contentinfo". Please remove the extra footers or change their roles.
rule.summary.aria_content_in_landmark: All content should be placed inside of a landmark region, such as a <main>, <header>, <nav>, and <footer>.
rule.desc.aria_content_in_landmark:
Navigating Using Landmarks

Web content is typically laid out in consistent patterns: a header at the top, page navigation menus, main content, sidebars, footers, etc. Standard sections are known as "landmarks," and they help assistive technology (AT) users orient themselves and easily navigate to various regions of a page.

When content is placed outside of any landmark regions, it can be difficult for AT users to find it. This is especially true for screen reader users, who may not be able to see the visual layout of the page. To ensure that all content is reachable, it should be placed inside of a landmark region, such as a <main> element or an element with a role="main" attribute.

Best Practices

  • Ensure that all primary content is placed inside of a landmark region
  • Use landmark elements like <main>, <header>, <nav>, and <footer> where possible

For More Information

WebAIM.org: Semantic Structure and ARIA Landmark Roles

W3.org: Using ARIA Landmarks
rule.summary.aria_descendant_valid: Certain interactive elements, like buttons, checkboxes, progressbars, sliders, and tabs, are not permitted to contain other interactive elements inside of them. Please remove any nested interactive elements.
rule.desc.aria_descendant_valid:
Nested Interactive Elements

When users click on interactive elements, such as buttons or checkboxes, they expect certain predictable behavior. Placing buttons inside of checkboxes, sliders inside of tabs, or similar combinations can create confusion for users and inconsistent behavior across different browsers.

ARIA Roles and HTML Tags Which Only Permit Non-Interactive Elements to be Nested Inside
ARIA RoleHTML Equivalent (if Exists)
"button"<button>
"checkbox"<input[type="checkbox"]>
"img"<img>
"math"<math>
"menuitemcheckbox"None
"menuitemradio"None
"option"<option>
"progressbar"<progress>
"radio"<input[type="radio"]>
"scrollbar"<input[type="range"]>
"separator"<hr>
"slider"<input[type="range"]>
"switch"<input[type="checkbox"]>
"tab"None

Best Practices

  • Do not place interactive elements inside of other interactive elements
  • Use non-interactive elements like <div>, <span>, or <section> to group related content inside of interactive elements

For More Information

W3.org: Allowed Descendants of ARIA Roles
rule.summary.aria_hidden_nontabbable: The highlighted element is hidden from screen readers or can't be reached with a keyboard. It is probably contained inside of another element with a role="presentation" or an aria-hidden="true" value.
rule.desc.aria_hidden_nontabbable:
Invisible and Inaccessible Elements

Page content is considered "visible" even when it is offscreen, as long as all it takes is scrolling up or down to view it. In contrast, content is "invisible" if it doesn't display on screen without some other form of user interaction. This is usually the case with drop-downs and accordion menus, which require a user to click before opening.

Whenever content is invisible on screen, it should also be inaccessible to screen readers and keyboard users. This is usually accomplished by placing the content inside of an element with a role="presentation", aria-hidden="true", or aria-expanded="false" value. When invisible content becomes visible, it should become accessible to screen readers and keyboard users, as well.

Best Practices

  • When content is invisible, make sure that you cannot reach it using a keyboard.
  • When content is visible, ensure that it is accessible to screen readers and keyboard users.
  • If content can toggle visibility, such as when opening and closing an accordion menu, ensure that it toggles its role, aria-hidden, or aria-expanded values to match.

For More Information

WebAIM.org: Keyboard Accessibility

W3.org: Keyboard (Level A), Fourth Rule of ARIA Use
rule.summary.download_keyboard_controlla: Ensure that this download link is accessible to keyboard users.
rule.desc.download_keyboard_controllable:
Keyboard Accessibility

Some users cannot use a mouse or trackpad due to physical limitations. When this is the case, they may have a custom device that helps them navigate. These devices translate interactions, from rough muscle control to voice commands, into equivalent keystrokes. Any mouse-based interaction, such as clicking on a link, should have a keyboard equivalent.

Keyboard Traps

A keyboard trap happens when a keyboard-only user is stuck in a content area and cannot 'tab' their way out. Additionally, the action may cause the user to lose track of their position on the page, forcing them to have to navigate all the way back.

Best Practices

All interactive elements from links to buttons should be tested in the following ways:

  • They should be reachable with a keyboard (usually by pressing tab and shift-tab to navigate)
  • They should be triggered with a keyboard (usually by pressing enter or spacebar)
  • If the interaction triggers a popup window, the keyboard focus should be moved to the popup when it opens
  • When the popup is closed, the keyboard focus should comes back to the original element

For More Information

WebAIM.org: Keyboard Accessibility

W3.org: Keyboard (Level A)
rule.summary.element_tabbable_visible: The highlighted section of the page can be reached with a keyboard but may not be visible. Confirm that if users can use the tab or arrow keys to reach a specific section, it is also visible on the screen.
rule.desc.element_tabbable_visible:
Keyboard Accessibility

Some users cannot use a mouse or trackpad due to physical limitations. When this is the case, they may have a custom device that helps them navigate. These devices translate interactions, from rough muscle control to voice commands, into equivalent keystrokes.

Keyboard Navigation

Normally, all interactive elements should be reachable without a mouse by using the arrow keys, tab, and shift + tab on the keyboard. When the user navigates this way, the item they are currently on should have a clear visual indicator that shows that it is active, usually a thick outline. In this case, it appears that there may be an interactive element that can be reached by the keyboard, but may be invisible, off-screen, or too small to see.

Best Practices

  • Confirm that the highlighted area is reachable with a keyboard (usually by pressing tab and shift + tab to navigate)
  • Confirm that when the element is focused on, that it is visible on screen with a clear visual indicator that it has received focus, like an outline.

For More Information

WebAIM.org: Keyboard Accessibility

W3.org: Keyboard (Level A)
rule.summary.frame_src_valid: The highlighted content comes from another website. Please verify that it doesn't introduce any accessibility barriers. For instance, videos should be captioned, images should have alternative text, buttons and controls should work with keyboards as well as mice, etc.
rule.desc.frame_src_valid:
Reviewing External Content

UDOIT cannot run an accessibility scan on content when it is embedded from another website. However, you can should review the content manually to ensure that it is accessible. The primary things to check for are:

  • Videos should have captions or transcripts
  • Images should have alternative text
  • Text should use proper headings and have strong color contrast
  • Buttons and controls should work with keyboards as well as mice

Best Practices

  • Always review external content manually to ensure that it is accessible
  • If needed, consider contacting an Accessibility Specialist for assistance

For More Information

W3.org: Easy Checks - A First Review of Web Accessibility
rule.summary.img_longdesc_misuse: The longdesc attribute should link to an HTML file that gives more context to an image.
rule.desc.img_longdesc_misuse:
Using the longdesc Attribute

Alternative text is the standard way to provide visual information as text to those who use assistive technologies like screen readers to process web content. However, alternative text is designed to be short and concise, which may not be enough for complex images, diagrams, or other visual content. Because of this, the longdesc attribute can be applied to an image that requires more text to provide equivalent information.

Best Practices

  • Ensure that the longdesc attribute value has a valid URL of an HTML page, with a text description of the image.
  • If your longdesc attribute appears inconsistent across browsers, consider using the aria-describedby attribute to link to extensive text on the same page.

For More Information

W3.org: The 'longdesc' Attribute

WebAIM.org: ARIA Labels and Descriptions
rule.summary.media_keyboard_controllable: Ensure audio and video media have keyboard accessible controls to play, pause, adjust volume, and turn on captions.
rule.desc.media_keyboard_controllable:
Media Should Have Keyboard Controls

HTML elements such as audio and video embed media onto the page. Keyboard accessibility is important in this case, as users with motor and visual disabilities will need a way to navigate the media settings and options.

Best Practices

  • If using custom audio/video controls, make sure they're also controllable via keyboard
  • Confirm that the default controls of the media player allow easy keyboard input
rule.summary.page_title_exists: Every page should have a title that describes its content. This title appears in the browser tab and helps users identify the page when they have multiple tabs open.
rule.desc.page_title_exists:
Page Titles

The title of a web page is one of the most important pieces of information for users. It appears in the browser tab, bookmarks, and search engine results, helping users identify and navigate to the page. A clear and descriptive title also helps users with cognitive disabilities understand the content and purpose of the page.

Page titles are not visible in the page content. Instead, they must be added in the HTML code using the <title> element inside the <head> section.

Best Practices

  • Make sure every page has a unique and descriptive title
  • Keep titles concise; they should fit on a browser tab
  • Avoid using generic titles like "Home" or "Untitled"

For More Information

W3.org: Page Titled (Level A)

WebAIM.org: Page Titles
rule.summary.style_focus_visible: Ensure keyboard focus is visible when an item is tabbed on. CSS styles like border or outline may impact focus indicator visibility, preventing some users from knowing which section has keyboard focus.
rule.desc.style_focus_visible:
Focus Indicators Should Be Visible

Most websites provide a default focus indicator for when keyboard users navigate the page. However, this can be altered by Cascading Style Sheets (CSS) styles, and potentially hide it, preventing a user from knowing which element has focus while navigating content.

Best Practices

  • Use the default focus indicator for the platform or adjust the CSS styling to make the keyboard focus highly visible.
rule.summary.table_headers_related: In complicated data tables where cells are merged, cells may need to be individually linked to their headers using the headers attribute. If you are using a table editor, this should be done automatically. If you are not using a table editor, you may need to add the headers attribute manually.
rule.desc.table_headers_related:
Table Headers

Data tables should have headers to help users understand the data. This is especially important for screen reader users, who may not be able to see the table layout. For simple tables, you can define the first row, first column, or both as headers. If your table is more complicated, you may need to use the scope attribute for headers or the headers attribute for cells to indicate which headers apply to which cells.

Best Practices

  • If a table is not for presenting data, identify it as a layout table.
  • Use the th element instead of td to define headers for rows and columns.

For More Information

WebAIM.org: Accessible Data Tables

W3.org: Tables Tutorial
rule.summary.table_summary_redundant: The highlighted table has a <caption> element that describes its contents as well as a summary that duplicates the same information. The duplicate summary should be removed.
rule.desc.table_summary_redundant:
Table Captions and Summaries

Data tables should have a caption that describes their contents. This helps all users understand the purpose of the table, and is especially important for screen reader users, who may not be able to see the table layout. The caption should be concise and clearly describe what the table is about.

In addition to a caption, complex data tables may also need a summary that provides more detailed information about the table's structure and content. However, if the summary simply duplicates the information in the caption, it is unnecessary and should be removed.

Best Practices

  • Use the <caption> element to provide a concise description of each data table's contents
  • If a summary is needed for complex tables, ensure that it provides additional information beyond what is in the caption
  • Add the summary in a paragraph or other element with a unique id (like <p id="table-summary1">...</p>), then add the "aria-describedby" attribute to the table (like <table aria-describedby="table-summary1">...</table>)

    For More Information

    W3.org: Caption & Summary

    WebAIM.org: Creating Accessible Tables
